intro: Sida killipii, commonly known as Killip's mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems, heart-shaped leaves, and showy pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. Sida killipii is typically found in arid or semi-arid environments, growing in disturbed soils and along roadsides. It is an annual herb that plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators.
